verses.text: Then he began to speak to them in parables: “A man planted a vineyard, set a hedge around it, dug a winepress, and built a tower. He rented it out to others and went to another country.
verses.comment: Jesus begins with a parable that recalls Isaiah 5, identifying himself with God’s authority over Israel. The vineyard represents God’s people entrusted to spiritual caretakers.

verses.text: At harvest time, he sent a servant to the tenants to collect some of the fruit of the vineyard.
verses.comment: The servants symbolize the prophets sent by God to his people to seek faithfulness and spiritual fruits.

verses.text: But they seized him, beat him, and sent him away empty-handed.
verses.comment: Israel’s leaders often rejected the prophets, reflecting hardened resistance to God’s message.

verses.text: Again, he sent another servant to them, and they struck him on the head and insulted him.
verses.comment: This shows the cycle of rejection and abuse towards God’s messengers through Israel’s history.

verses.text: He sent yet another, and they killed him. He sent many others; some they beat and some they killed.
verses.comment: Many prophets faced harsh treatment, including execution, underscoring the gravity of Israel’s rejection of God’s word.

verses.text: He had one left, a beloved son. He sent him to them last of all, thinking, ‘They will respect my son.’
verses.comment: The ‘beloved son’ is a direct Christological reference to Jesus. This echoes divine sonship.

verses.text: But those tenants said to one another, ‘This is the heir. Come, let’s kill him, and the inheritance will be ours.’
verses.comment: In rejecting the son, the leaders claim the vineyard for themselves, prefiguring Jesus’ death.

verses.text: So they seized him, killed him, and threw him out of the vineyard.
verses.comment: Jesus’ crucifixion outside Jerusalem is typologically represented here.

verses.text: What then will the owner of the vineyard do? He will come and destroy those tenants and give the vineyard to others.
verses.comment: This warns of judgment on the faithless leaders, and the passing on of responsibility to new stewards, which is historically seen in the apostolic succession.

verses.text: Have you not read this Scripture: ‘The stone that the builders rejected has become the cornerstone;
verses.comment: Jesus is the cornerstone prophesied in the Psalms; his rejection and exaltation are central to God’s plan.

verses.text: This was the Lord’s doing, and it is marvelous in our eyes’?”
verses.comment: Emphasizes divine action in establishing Jesus’ authority and role, foreseen by prophecy.

verses.text: They wanted to arrest him, for they realized he had spoken this parable against them. But they feared the crowd, so they left him and went away.
verses.comment: The religious leaders recognize the pointed critique of their stewardship, yet hesitate due to Jesus’ popularity.

verses.text: Later they sent some Pharisees and Herodians to Jesus to trap him with his words.
verses.comment: Political and religious factions unite against Jesus, highlighting growing opposition.

verses.text: They came and said, “Teacher, we know that you are true, and that you do not care for anyone’s opinion; for you are not swayed by appearances, but truly teach the way of God. Is it lawful to pay taxes to Caesar or not? Should we pay, or should we not?”
verses.comment: Flattering words aim to trap Jesus in a political dilemma, combining theological and civic concerns.

verses.text: But he, knowing their hypocrisy, said to them, “Why do you test me? Bring me a denarius so I can look at it.”
verses.comment: Jesus exposes their insincerity and uses a physical coin to illustrate his teaching.

verses.text: They brought one. He said to them, “Whose image and inscription is this?” They replied, “Caesar’s.”
verses.comment: The coin’s inscription denotes civil authority; Jesus leads them to a principle transcending mere politics.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, “Give to Caesar the things that are Caesar’s, and to God the things that are God’s.” And they marveled at him.
verses.comment: Jesus affirms legitimate civic authority, but distinguishes the higher claim of God. Implied is the human person’s belonging to God, as we bear his image spiritually.

verses.text: Then some Sadducees, who say there is no resurrection, came to him and questioned him.
verses.comment: Sadducees reject resurrection, so their challenge tests Jesus’ teaching on life after death.

verses.text: “Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if a man’s brother dies and leaves a wife but no child, the man must marry the widow and raise children for his brother.
verses.comment: They cite the law of levirate marriage, using the Torah’s authority to frame their hypothetical.

verses.text: There were seven brothers. The first married and died, leaving no offspring.
verses.comment: Setting up an exaggerated scenario to challenge belief in resurrection.

verses.text: The second married her and died, leaving no offspring; and the third did the same.
verses.comment: Repetition underscores the intended absurdity of their scenario.

verses.text: None of the seven left any children. Last of all, the woman died too.
verses.comment: Completes the scenario, raising the question for the resurrected state.

verses.text: In the resurrection, when they rise again, whose wife will she be? For all seven had married her.”
verses.comment: They attempt to show the resurrection as implausible using human marriage practices.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, “Is not this the reason you are wrong, because you know neither the Scriptures nor the power of God?
verses.comment: Jesus highlights both ignorance of revealed truth and God’s power to transcend earthly limitations.

verses.text: For when they rise from the dead, they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like angels in heaven.
verses.comment: Heavenly life supersedes earthly practices; resurrection transforms existence beyond physical marriage.

verses.text: And concerning the dead being raised, have you not read in the book of Moses, how God spoke to him at the bush, saying, ‘I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob’?
verses.comment: Jesus cites Exodus, showing that God’s covenant continues even after physical death.

verses.text: He is not the God of the dead but of the living. You are very mistaken.”
verses.comment: God’s life-giving nature affirms both the resurrection and immortality of the soul.

verses.text: One of the scribes came and heard them debating. He saw that Jesus answered them well and asked, “Which commandment is the most important of all?”
verses.comment: The question concerns the heart of true religious observance. Religious leaders debated such priorities.

verses.text: Jesus answered, “The most important is, ‘Hear, O Israel: The Lord our God, the Lord is one.
verses.comment: This affirms monotheism and the Shema, central to Jewish faith and law.

verses.text: And you shall love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind and with all your strength.’
verses.comment: True worship involves the whole person—heart, soul, mind, and strength—calling for complete devotion.

verses.text: The second is this, ‘You shall love your neighbor as yourself.’ There is no other commandment greater than these.”
verses.comment: Neighbor-love complements love of God, uniting the Law’s demands in charity. Authentic fulfillment is realized in lived holiness within community.

verses.text: The scribe said to him, “You are right, Teacher. You have truly said that he is one, and there is no other besides him;
verses.comment: Acknowledges Jesus’ teaching as consistent with foundational Jewish beliefs.

verses.text: And to love him with all the heart, with all the understanding, and with all the strength, and to love one’s neighbor as oneself, is more than all burnt offerings and sacrifices.”
verses.comment: Inner devotion and charity surpass ritual acts, prioritizing spiritual worship.

verses.text: When Jesus saw that he answered wisely, he said to him, “You are not far from the kingdom of God.” And after that no one dared to ask him any more questions.
verses.comment: A sincere understanding of the Law draws one close to God’s reign, pointing implicitly toward attaining it through faith in Christ and his teachings.

verses.text: While Jesus was teaching in the temple, he said, “How can the scribes say that the Christ is the son of David?
verses.comment: This phrase invites reflection on the Messiah’s identity—not only Davidic descent but also something greater.

verses.text: David himself, by the Holy Spirit, said, ‘The Lord said to my Lord, “Sit at my right hand, until I put your enemies under your feet.”’
verses.comment: David, inspired by the Spirit, prophesies of Christ’s heavenly enthronement, pointing toward Jesus’ divinity through possession of divine authority.

verses.text: David himself calls him ‘Lord.’ So how can he be his son?” And the large crowd listened to him gladly.
verses.comment: Jesus reveals his messianic identity as both Son and Lord, implying his divinity and eternality, and the mystery of the Incarnation—God made man.

verses.text: And in his teaching he said, “Beware of the scribes, who like to walk around in long robes, and love greetings in the marketplaces
verses.comment: Jesus warns against external religiosity and the dangers of pride among religious leaders.

verses.text: and the best seats in the synagogues and places of honor at banquets.
verses.comment: Preference for status over service contrasts with true leadership, which is humble and sacrificial.

verses.text: They devour widows’ houses and for appearance’s sake offer long prayers. They will receive greater condemnation.”
verses.comment: False piety and exploitation invite divine judgment; authentic faith models compassion and justice.

verses.text: Jesus sat down opposite the treasury and watched the people putting money into the offering box. Many rich people put in large sums.
verses.comment: Jesus observes not only the act but the spirit in which offerings are made, stressing the importance of intention and sacrifice.

verses.text: A poor widow came and put in two small copper coins, worth only a few cents.
verses.comment: The widow’s gift, minimal in earthly value, reveals deep faith and generosity—highlighting holiness through humble self-giving.

verses.text: He called his disciples and said to them, “Truly I tell you, this poor widow has put in more than all those who are contributing to the offering box.
verses.comment: True spiritual value is measured not by quantity but by the extent of self-giving, echoing the call to personal sacrifice and trust in divine providence.

verses.text: For they all gave out of their wealth, but she out of her poverty has given everything she had, all she had to live on.”
verses.comment: Perfect self-gift is pleasing to God; this foreshadows Christ’s total offering and models faith that trusts God for one’s needs, a principle sustaining the Church throughout history.
